Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: Planning for Renewables: Regional Transmission Organizations Managing Tension and Networking Innovation

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Division.LongName: Divn Of Social and Economic Sciences

Award.AbstractNarration:
This project addresses the process of organizational adaptation among "Regional Transmission Organizations" (RTOs), which coordinate the movement of electricity to more than two-thirds of households in the United States. RTOs are highly complex socio-technical organizations that are challenged to facilitate fundamental transformations in how electricity is produced and delivered, driven by individual state mandates requiring increased use of renewable fuel sources (primarily from variable sources such as wind and solar energy). RTOs must adapt to these mandates through policy innovation, a difficult organizational problem since decision-making by RTOs happens within a complex negotiation framework involving a large number of voluntary external stakeholders (e.g., electricity generating companies, regulators, consumer and environmental advocates). The focus of this comparative analysis among three RTOs (serving the Mid-Atlantic, Midwest and California) is to understand how, why, and when these networks of conflicting stakeholders can lead to innovation. The approach blends direct observation of policy-formation processes with semi-structured interviews in an empirical investigation of the configuration of stakeholder networks within RTOs and the communication strategies employed by RTO stakeholders within the policy process.

RTOs play a critical role in the transition to more sustainable energy systems, making decisions that are pivotal to environmental quality, economic growth and security, and social well-being. The focus of this research, which is designed to understand processes of communication in complex dynamic organizations, will provide direct insights that can contribute to the sustainable transformation of similar organizations and infrastructures critical to social well-being. Our program of engaged scholarship includes the gathering of primary data on stakeholder perceptions of policy-formation processes within RTOs, as well as meetings and workshops held jointly with university researchers, industry practitioners, and regulators.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The National Science Foundation’s Science of Organizations program selected Boise State, the University of Minnesota, and Penn State University to complete a four-year, $500,000 collaborative project entitled Planning for Renewables: Regional Transmission Organizations Managing Tension and Networking Innovation.  The project resulted in numerous peer reviewed publications, dozens of conference presentations, several workshops, case studies and book chapters, and one completed dissertation (a second dissertation supported by the project will be completed by August 15, 2017). Numerous presentations were also given to industry, government, and NGO stakeholder groups, including PJM and MISO, two of the organizations the team studied over the course of the research.

The team performed a comparative study of three Regional Transmission Organizations (RTOs) that coordinate delivery of electricity to more than two-thirds of households in the United States.  The three RTOs were PJM, which stretches from New Jersey to Illinois; California Independent System Operator (CAISO); and the Midcontinent Independent System Operator (MISO), which includes much of the Midwest.  Driven by individual state mandates requiring increased use of renewable sources like wind and solar power, RTOs are challenged to facilitate fundamental transformations in how electricity is produced and delivered. RTOs must adapt to these mandates through policy innovation, generating new planning and market constructs to meet these goals while maintaining reliability of the grid.  Data was collected via direct observation of 21 policy-formation processes and 54 semi-structured interviews over three years.

The team’s analysis of the interview data revealed three sets of significant results to report, one for each of the three RTOs on which the work focuses.  For PJM, the interviews with stakeholder process participants have revealed a number of shifts in the (a) composition of the stakeholder population? (b) types of decisions that stakeholders are asked to consider? and (c) complexity of interactions between the number of functions that the RTO is asked to perform. These shifts have had direct and identifiable consequences on the success of the stakeholder process within PJM at moving issues to resolution, and have shifted political power within the PJM stakeholder process in measurable and unanticipated ways. The research on CAISO focused on governance issues and the establishment of the real time energy imbalance market (EIM).  It revealed the importance of cultural authority and the emergence of a new collective identity as the organization expands its services and crosses longstanding material and symbolic boundaries. The research on MISO revealed that stakeholders use different forms of legitimacy to influence RTO decisions. One form of legitimacy is expressed through socially accepted language and expression of ideas. For example, many stakeholders hinted that expertise in engineering was necessary in order to discuss system integration for renewable energy interests. Others stated that market and planning processes involve distinct social exchanges, though conceptually the two concepts integrate.

The project had substantial intellectual merit in four distinct areas. First, the research contributed to organization studies, communication, science and technology studies, policy analysis, and engineering by going inside the black box of renewable energy integration to focus on change in complex socio-technical systems. Second, the researchers adopted a framework for the RTO as a boundary organization and focused on stakeholder-network structures and communication strategies that facilitated or impeded innovation. Third, the proposed work built new linkages between Critical Management Theory and the network structure of organizations to develop holistic organizational analysis frameworks encompassing 1) the structure of information flow within organizations, and 2) specific strategies used by actors within organizational networks that influence information quantity and flow. Fourth, the comparative analysis of multiple stakeholder networks facilitated the identification of differences between stakeholder network structures among the three RTOs and increased the understanding of linkages between these structures and differences in how each RTO innovates.

The research had broader impacts because it focused on understanding processes of communication in complex dynamic organizations like RTOs and provided direct insights that contributed to the sustainable transformation of organizations and infrastructures critical to social well-being. The research was timely in that RTOs are making decisions that are pivotal to environmental quality, economic growth, security and social well-being. The project offered a unique and strategic focus on poorly understood yet crucially important organizations and integrated traditionally-separate areas of inquiry; the focus on policy formation within complex boundary organizations has implications beyond the electricity industry. In addition to engaging graduate students at each of the participating universities, the project directly involved key government and industry stakeholders from the RTOs, practitioners in planning for renewable energy integration, and leaders in the field of management science. Broader impacts were also assured through a robust dissemination phase of the project, which involved meetings and workshops held jointly with university researchers, industry practitioners, and regulators.
